properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Lake Fyans, Pomonal, Bellfield, Halls Gap
properties.webBody:
• The Grampians National Park, Bellfield fire is contained. 
  • Fire crews have built control lines around the fire edge and is no longer spreading. Hot spots within the fire area are being monitored and extinguished.
  • The threat to communities is reduced. 
The Grampians National Park remains closed to visitors.
  • Parks Victoria are planning for a partial re-opening (pending weather and fire conditions) this week. 
  • For further information visit www.parks.vic.gov.au
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.

If the Situation Changes or you feel unsafe you should leave
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Fire crews remain in the area monitoring conditions and treating fire damaged trees, for your safety please move away if you are asked.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
  • There is a Do Not Drink Tap Water Advice issued for Pomonal.
Road Closures 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
  • Please obey all road signage and speed restrictions.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 19/02/2024 08:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text: ADVICE - BUSHFIRE - Stay Informed Incident Location: Grampians National Park, Bellfield Issue Date: Sunday 18 February 2024, 06:29 pm Next Update: Monday 19 February 2024, 08:30 pm More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/32894/moreinfo - The Grampians National Park, Bellfield fire is contained. - Fire crews have built control lines around the fire edge and is no longer spreading. Hot spots within the fire area are being monitored and extinguished. - The threat to communities is reduced. The Grampians National Park remains closed to visitors. - Parks Victoria are planning for a partial re-opening (pending weather and fire conditions) this week. - For further information visit www.parks.vic.gov.au There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 
  • High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
  • Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
  • This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes.
Warning signs have been installed at the lake.

You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe. 
What you should do:
  • Visit Parks Victoria website (https://www.parks.vic.gov.au/places-to-see/parks/lake-bolac-highway-park) for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at the lake.
Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.
Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 
Agriculture information: 
  • Irrigation water contaminated with blue-green algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. 
  • Fruit and vegetables grown in the affected areas are safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding blue-green algae
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is  green as a result of the algae bloom.
Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating. 
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected area. 
This message was issued by Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action.

The next update is expected by 31/03/2024 05:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
COMMUNITY INFORMATION - BLUE GREEN ALGAE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Lake Bolac
Issue Date: Tuesday 23 January 2024, 03:14 pm
Next Update: Sunday 31 March 2024, 05:20 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/32563/moreinfo

This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 
- High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
- The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
- Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
- This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes. 



Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 
You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for Monash and Greater Dandenong. 

This message is being issued for Monash, Knox and Greater Dandenong areas
  • Emergency Services are currently responding to high priority incidents to support access and egress to homes and damage to homes to support liveability. Home owners should consider insurance and other supports for tree removal other to providing access and egress.
  • To ensure your safety, do not drive or walk over downed power lines. Call you electricity company to report any faults.
  • Traffic Conditions are poor due to downed trees and traffic lights not working. Please drive to the conditions of the road and follow road rules where applicable/possible. In the event of unmanned intersections with inoperable traffic lights, come to a complete stop, proceed with caution at low speeds and at all time respecting other road users in the same position where no clear right of way exist.
  • Ongoing works continues within the affected storm areas. Please be mindful when travelling within these locations, first responders are still working tirelessly to return services to the communities.
Weekend Travellers

  • Ongoing clean up works continue in the impacted Mount Dandenong area. 
  • Please avoid unnecessary travel or visitation to the area as emergency services, residents and business owners continue clean up works. 
  • There are still several roads impacted by fallen trees making driving hazardous. 

South East Water pressure sewer customers
  • Experiencing issues with your pressure sewer due to a power outage? Please contact South East Water immediately on 13 28 12 or email faults@sew.com.au. Issues may include slow drainage, strange noises or overflowing sewerage.

Generators
  • Never use generators indoors or in enclosed areas this can be deadly. Generators emit carbon monoxide that you cannot see or smell, and it can quickly cause carbon monoxide poisoning and asphyxiation.
  • Never plug the generator into a wall socket or the switch board to try to power the house. It is dangerous for you, your neighbours and utility workers.
  • Keep the generator out of dry grass to prevent the exhaust from igniting it. Ensure it is kept dry and away from rain or wet conditions.
  • For more information how to use generators safely go to the Energy Safe Website
Roads and Transport
  • For up to date information on road closures, visit VicRoads Traffic Website.


Further information:
Refer to your local Council Website for further information and support.


There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.

 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this incident. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Generators emit carbon monoxide that you cannot see or smell, and it can quickly cause carbon monoxide poisoning and asphyxiation. - Never plug the generator into a wall socket or the switch board to try to power the house. properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Italian Gully, Ross Creek, Smythesdale, Enfield, Napoleons, Newtown, Scarsdale, Staffordshire Reef
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Enfield, Italian Gully, Napoleons, Newtown, Ross Creek, Scarsdale, Smythesdale, Staffordshire Reef. 

  • This Community Information message replaces the Advice message issued at 9.21am Friday 16 February.
  • The fire that started in Newtown and spread into the Ross Creek State Forest is now under control. 
  • There is no immediate threat to the community however smoke and fire activity may still be visible in the area. 
  • Firefighters will continue to attend to the fire. Heavy vehicles and aircraft may also be seen operating in the area.
  • Ross Creek State Forest tracks in and around the fire area are closed to ensure firefighter and public safety. 
Fire fighting activities are still occuring. Do not enter closed roads.

Burnt areas are dangerous. Hazardous trees can fall at any time causing serious injury or death. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 19/02/2024 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:

- Firefighters will continue to attend to the fire. Heavy vehicles and aircraft may also be seen operating in the area. 
- Ross Creek State Forest tracks in and around the fire area are closed to ensure firefighter and public safety. 



Fire fighting activities are still occuring. Do not enter closed roads.

Burnt areas are dangerous. Hazardous trees can fall at any time causing serious injury or death.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Dadswells Bridge. 

  • The bushfire at Grampians National Park, Mt Stapylton is contained. 
  • Fire crews have built containment lines around the fire edge and it is no longer spreading. 
  • Firefighters are working to identify and extinguish hot spots within the fire area.  
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
  • Grampians National Park remains closed to visitors. Pending weather and fire conditions Parks Victoria are planning a partial re-opening this week. For further information www.parks.vic.gov.au
  • Speed restrictions apply along the Western Highway. 
There is no immediate threat to the community, you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 19/02/2024 07:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • Smoke information: Smoke can affect people’s health.  For more information visit: https://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text: COMMUNITY INFORMATION - BUSHFIRE - Stay Informed Incident Location: Grampians National Park, Mt Stapylton Issue Date: Sunday 18 February 2024, 06:27 pm Next Update: Monday 19 February 2024, 07:30 pm More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/32893/moreinfo This Community Information message is being issued for Dadswells Bridge. - The bushfire at Grampians National Park, Mt Stapylton is contained. - Fire crews have built containment lines around the fire edge and it is no longer spreading. - Firefighters are working to identify and extinguish hot spots within the fire area. - Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. - Grampians National Park remains closed to visitors. Pending weather and fire conditions Parks Victoria are planning a partial re-opening this week. For further information www.parks.vic.gov.au - Speed restrictions apply along the Western Highway. There is no immediate threat to the community, you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice is being issued for Pomonal.

  • As of 10:00 am 16 February, the tap water at Pomonal continues to be unsafe to drink.  
  • The town's water supply is currently not suitable for drinking and boiling the water will not make it safe to drink. 
  • A drinking water trailer will be available at the Pomonal General Store to fill bottles and containers. 
  • This is to minimise any risk to your health and in the interests of protecting public health. 
  • This advice has been issued following consultation with the Department of Health after fires impacted the infrastructure which supplies water in the town. 
  • While this 'Do Not Drink Tap Water' notice is in place, customers must not use the current water supply for drinking, preparing beverages, washing and preparing food, preparing baby formula, brushing teeth or making ice. 
  • If you experience any symptoms such as vomiting and diarrhoea in the coming days, please seek medical advice and let your doctor know about the 'Do Not Drink Tap Water' notice. 
  • We ask that you share this advice with neighbours, friends and visitors in Pomonal. 
  • We are working to assess damage and resume water supply as soon as possible.
  • We will keep customers informed as the situation changes. More info: gwmwater.org.au/service-disruptions
  • This is an updated Advice message that replaces the Advice issued at 11:12 am on 16 February.
Tap water is not safe to drink in Pomonal and boiling the tap water will not make it safe to drink. A drinking water trailer will be available at the Pomonal General Store to fill bottles and containers.
What you should do: 
  • Do not drink tap water.
  • You should only drink bottled water. 
  • You should seek emergency medical care from a hospital or by calling Triple Zero (000) if you have drunk tap water. 
  • You should seek immediate medical attention from your local doctor or by calling Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.  
  • If you get contaminated tap water on your skin, you should immediately rinse it off with bottled water.   
  • If you are unsure if the water is safe to drink, you should not drink it.
  • Any clothes or dishes washed in contaminated or potentially contaminated water should be rewashed.   
It is unsafe to use tap water for: 
  • Food preparation, cleaning food or preparing baby formula. 
  • Cleaning dishes or clothing.
  • Animals - pets should be given bottled water to drink.
Maintaining personal hygiene: 
  • It is unsafe to use tap water for cleaning yourself or children.
  • Use hand sanitiser after going to the bathroom and before you consume food. 
  • Use disposable baby wipe products that are not soap based without water to clean yourself.   
  • Treating water with chlorine (bleach) will not make it safe to drink.    

 
  

Impacts in your area: 
  • You can source drinking water from Pomonal General Store. 
  • We are working to assess damage and resume water supply as soon as possible. We will keep customers informed as the situation changes. More info: gwmwater.org.au/service-disruptions
This message was issued by DH.  

The next update is expected by 19/02/2024 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.   

Use multiple sources to stay informed:  
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.    
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.  
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text: ADVICE - DRINKING WATER - Do Not Drink Tap Water Incident Location: Pomonal Issue Date: Friday 16 February 2024, 12:07 pm Next Update: Monday 19 February 2024, 12:00 pm More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/32874/moreinfo This Advice is being issued for Pomonal. - As of 10:00 am 16 February, the tap water at Pomonal continues to be unsafe to drink. - The town's water supply is currently not suitable for drinking and boiling the water will not make it safe to drink. - A drinking water trailer will be available at the Pomonal General Store to fill bottles and containers. - This is to minimise any risk to your health and in the interests of protecting public health. - This advice has been issued following consultation with the Department of Health after fires impacted the infrastructure which supplies water in the town. - While this 'Do Not Drink Tap Water' notice is in place, customers must not use the current water supply for drinking, preparing beverages, washing and preparing food, preparing baby formula, brushing teeth or making ice. - If you experience any symptoms such as vomiting and diarrhoea in the coming days, please seek medical advice and let your doctor know about the 'Do Not Drink Tap Water' notice. - We ask that you share this advice with neighbours, friends and visitors in Pomonal. - We are working to assess damage and resume water supply as soon as possible. - We will keep customers informed as the situation changes. More info: gwmwater.org.au/service-disruptions - This is an updated Advice message that replaces the Advice issued at 11:12 am on 16 February. Tap water is not safe to drink in Pomonal and boiling the tap water will not make it safe to drink. A drinking water trailer will be available at the Pomonal General Store to fill bottles and containers.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Avonsleigh, Clematis, Cockatoo, Emerald, Fielder, Lakeside, Menzies Creek, Nobelius, Wright, Macclesfield, Monbulk, The Patch
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for Emerald and Cockatoo communities.

  • Ongoing works continue within storm affected areas. Please be mindful when travelling within these locations, first responders are still working tirelessly to return services to the communities.
  • Cockatoo Community Drop-in Centre is located at Cockatoo Community Complex - 79 Pakenham Road, Cockatoo. It will remain open all weekend from 10.30am to 6.30pm. Shire and Emergency service representatives will be present to inform and support the community where possible.
  • Emerald Community Drop-in Centre is located at Worrell Reserve - Monbulk Road, Emerald. Power and showers are now available. You must bring your own toiletries, towels and phone chargers.
  • Emergency services are available to support high priority tree removal to support access and egress to homes and damage to home to support liveability. Home owners should consider insurance and other supports for tree removal other to providing access and egress.
  • To ensure your safety, do not drive or walk over downed power lines. Call your electricity company to report any faults.
Weekend travellers:
  • Please avoid unnecessary travel or visitation to the area as emergency services, residents and business owners continue clean up works. 
  • There are still several roads impacted by fallen trees making driving hazardous. 
Yarra Valley Water pressure sewer customers
  • If you are experiencing issues with your pressure sewer due to a power outage, contact the Yarra Valley Water Faults & Emergencies team on 13 27 62. 
  • Issues may include slow drainage, strange noises or overflowing sewerage.
Generators
  • Never use generators indoors or in enclosed areas, that can be deadly. Generators emit carbon monoxide that you cannot see or smell, and it can very quickly cause carbon monoxide poisoning and asphyxiation.
  • Never plug a generator into a wall socket or switchboard to power a house.
  • Keep the generator out of dry grass to prevent the exhaust from igniting it. Ensure it is kept dry and away from rain or wet conditions.
  • For more information how to use generators safely go to the Energy Safe website. (https://www.esv.vic.gov.au/community-safety/what-do-power-outage)
Road and transport
  • For up to date information on road closures, visit VicRoads Traffic website.
This is an update, replacing the Community Information message issued on Saturday.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this incident. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Ensure it is kept dry and away from rain or wet conditions. - For more information how to use generators safely go to the Energy Safe website. properties.sourceTitle: Midlands 99 - Staffordshire Reef - Staffordshire Reef Road
Goulburn 149 - Picola North - Barmah National Park
